title: Why after finishing a sentence do people say 'does that make sense'? - Quora

response.answer_text: I actually just recently read the answer to this in an English grammar book. Ending a sentence with, “Does that make sense?” Is a form of mitigating speech: for native English speakers, it's a little nicety that we tack on so that whatever we just said won't sound patronizing or too instructive or bossy or arrogant. By asking, “Does that make sense?” We accomplish 2 things: First, we deprecate ourselves ever-so-slightly, hinting that perhaps we, as communicators, didn't do such a good job of getting the message across. The psychological takeaway is that the other person feels deferred to and consulted, and possibly even sharper than us, even if none of that is true. The second thing it accomplishes is getting the listener to subconsciously buy into what we're saying. Studies show that if a salesman can get a person to nod or say “yes” while talking to him, the salesperson is more likely to clinch the deal. So when my boss says to me, “I'm going to have to ask you to pick up an extra shift next weekend because blah blah blah…does that make sense?” it comes across as softer than the command that it actually is. It forces my acknowledgement that I understand my boss's predicament and helps me feel a sense of importance or equality in being appealed to by her. And by saying “yes” [it makes sense to me] I'm already halfway to accepting my fate willingly.
